title: Video shows corrections officers brawling in elevator at Boston jail
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Video captures three correctional officers fighting in an elevator at Suffolk County House of Correction on Saturday morning.
The altercation began after a cup of coffee was knocked from one officer's hand, leading to a physical fight.
The Suffolk County Sheriff's Department is investigating and may impose disciplinary action following the elevator incident.

title: Asparagus could soon become Massachusetts’ official state vegetable
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Massachusetts legislators filed a bill to designate asparagus, also known as Hadley grass, as the official state vegetable.
Hadley, Massachusetts, once called the 'asparagus capital of the world,' played a significant role in asparagus production.
The bill aims to highlight regional pride and could possibly boost economic or tourism opportunities for the state.

title: Paula Cole wants to spend Valentine’s Day with you
author: Lauren Daley
bullets: Paula Cole to perform Valentine's Day concert at Groton Hill Music Center, Groton.
Cole plans 'This Fire: 30' anniversary tour, including a Boston stop on September 18.
Releasing 'Sonic Memoir', a 64-track archival set, coinciding with her tour.

title: Boston meteorologists say Monday’s storm is ‘trending toward a miss’
author: John Waller
bullets: Meteorologists report the storm expected Monday will likely miss Boston as it tracks south and east.
Cindy Fitzgibbon of WCVB predicts only minimal coastal flurries, with most precipitation staying offshore.
Forecasts for Boston anticipate a dry, seasonable weekend with milder temperatures in the 40s next week.

title: 5 best new restaurant openings and dining updates in Boston (Feb. 12, 2026)
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Jason Santos' Citrus & Salt is opening a second location in Burlington with a patio and private dining by summer 2026.
Moro Mou by Xenia Hospitality Group to offer a blend of Greek and Japanese cuisines in Seaport's 15-seat omakase spot.
The Down Low in Woburn offers Detroit-style pizza, cocktails, and live entertainment, bringing a Boston experience to the suburbs.

title: Nikola Vucevic, Celtics roll into All-Star break with blowout win over Bulls: 7 takeaways
author: Tom Westerholm
bullets: Boston Celtics defeated the Chicago Bulls 124-105, entering the All-Star break with a strong performance.
Nikola Vucevic contributed 19 points, 11 rebounds, and four 3-pointers off the bench against his former team.
Payton Pritchard scored 26 points, while Jordan Walsh added 16 with strong defensive play for the Celtics.

title: ‘Modern day concentration camp’: Irish man living in Boston area has been in ICE detention for 5 months
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Irish man Seamus Culleton, living in Boston, detained by ICE for five months after overstaying his visa since 2009.
Culleton, married to an American citizen, complains of poor conditions in El Paso ICE detention, including inadequate hygiene.
Culleton missed green card interview; lawyer disputes legal process, citing lack of removal notice and contested signed documents.

title: Will Patriots move on from Stefon Diggs? Maye says WR has a lot ‘left in the tank’
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Stefon Diggs could be a salary cap casualty despite surpassing 1,000 receiving yards for the Patriots in 2025.
Releasing Diggs before June 1 saves New England $16.8 million; post-June 1 saves $20.8 million in cap space.
Diggs, facing legal issues, has a court date Friday; the Patriots have expressed support for their wide receiver.

title: Watch: Maynard police, fire crews save dog from ‘pet owner’s worst nightmare’
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Maynard police and fire crews rescued a dog, Rufus, from icy waters at Mill Pond on Tuesday night.
The rescue operation, aided by a police drone, took less than ten minutes, and Rufus was unharmed.
Maynard Fire Chief Angela Lawless confirmed Rufus did not sustain serious injuries and is expected to fully recover.

title: Signal issues cause multiple delays and cancellations on at least 6 commuter rail lines
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Signal issues caused up to 50-minute delays on all 12 MBTA commuter rail lines Wednesday.
More than 25 train services were canceled due to signal problems on Wednesday.
The MBTA Blue Line experienced a power problem, prompting shuttle buses between Orient Heights and Wonderland.
